elements.content: Recently reported molecular host complexes, modified metal dibenzoylmethanates (metal DBMs), are extended to polynuclear host receptors by connecting metal DBM units with bridging ligand 4,4‘-dipyridyl (bipy). Series of new solvent-free as well as inclusion materials were prepared and studied with XRD, NMR, and other methods. Template-directed synthesis gave inclusion compounds with three distinct types of host receptors:  dimeric [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4], trimeric [Zn3(bipy)2(DBM)6], and polymeric [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n complexes. The dimeric complex was isolated as a solvent-free compound and as inclusion compounds with tert-butylbenzene and fluorobenzene (host per guest molar ratios of 1:1 and 1:2/3, respectively). The trimeric complex was prepared as an inclusion compound with DMSO (1:5 molar ratio). The polymeric complex was observed in inclusion compounds with fluorobenzene (host unit per guest molar ratio 1:2), tetrahydrofuran (1:2), 2-pentanone (1:2), bipy/DMSO (1:1/2:1/2), and bipy/tert-butylbenzene (1:1:2); a solvent-free material was obtained upon desolvation of tetrahydrofuran and 2-pentanone inclusions. The isolated host species have five-coordinated terminal zinc centers (two chelating DBMs and a singly coordinating bipy) and octahedrally coordinated intrinsic zinc centers (two chelating equatorial DBMs and two singly coordinating bipys). The bipy ligands bridge the zinc centers to give the di-, tri-, and polynuclear complexes. Nanosized voids between the DBM units coordinated to adjacent zinc centers form the basis for cages and channels in the inclusion materials. These voids have, in many cases, a typical size of between 1 and 2 nm and accommodate up to five molecules per single cavity or two rows of guest molecules in a single channel. When compared to previously reported metal DBMs, the multinuclear metal DBM receptors reported here exhibit stronger inclusion affinity and enhanced inclusion capacity.

The dimeric complex was isolated as a solvent-free compound and as inclusion compounds with tert-butylbenzene and fluorobenzene (host per guest molar ratios of 1:1 and 1:2/3, respectively). elements.content:
A class of molecular host complexes, modified metal dibenzoylmethanates (DBM), is extended to dimeric, trimeric, and polymeric host receptors by bridging metal DBM units with 4,4‘-dipyridyl.

 This is part VI of the series Modified Metal Dibenzoylmethanates and Their Clathrates; for the previous contributions see refs −5.

Introduction

Modified metal dibenzoylmethanates (metal DBMs) constitute a new class of host complexes that exhibit a remarkable versatility for producing soft supramolecular materials. The most attractive features of such soft materials are the wide variability in structure and selectivity, their easy conversion from one structure to another, and their transient response to external stimuli. These attributes provide good prospects for the use of these materials as “third-generation microporous frameworks”, “functional organic zeolite analogues”, “metrically engineered host frameworks”, supramolecular ion exchange materials, artificial ion conductors, “flexible sorbents” and “smart sorbents”, and materials switchable on the molecular level through coordination, isomerization, and other reversible in situ changes.

Modified metal dibenzoylmethanates (metal DBMs) constitute a new class of host complexes that exhibit a remarkable versatility for producing soft supramolecular materials. elements.content: The metal dibenzoylmethanate hosts studied so far are mononuclear complexes, as shown schematically in Figure e, where an M(II) center (a) is chelated by two DBM anions (b) in the equatorial plane and coordinated by two axial pyridine ligands (c). Modification of the archetype by changing the M(II) center and the pyridine ligand produced a variety of molecular host complexes with the ability to enclathrate a wide range of organic guests in their van der Waals lattices.

elements.content: Now this new family of materials has been explored further in a series of compounds in which the positioning of the metal DBM planar units is restricted by connecting them with a bidentate bridging ligand (Figure f); 4,4‘-dipyridyl (Figure d) has been selected in the present work. Most studies on coordination polymers employing di- and polypyridyl ligands reported to date were targeted toward constructing rigid frameworks and cavities, as this strategy allowed for a high degree of predictability. In contrast, the purpose of this work was to create materials with flexible architecture and at the same time to enhance the ability to entrap guest species. Some noncrystalline organic polymers possess this type of bulk property and have been studied already; however, they do not display the propensity for easily controlled assembly−disassembly inherent to most coordination polymers.

elements.content: Enhancing the inclusion propensity of known types of molecular hosts by extending them to oligomeric or polymeric species seems attractive. Surprisingly, so far only a few such attempts have been made. Most work in this field was performed on the macrocyclic metalloporphyrin hosts. Chelated complexes seem to have greater potential as they are more numerous and easier to synthesize, but only two reports on metal xanthates are available. This work shows the extension of the metal chelate hosts as a tool for the systematic generation of new oligomeric and polymeric materials with a very strong affinity for guest inclusion.

elements.content: Our group initiated the work on oligomerization with nickel and cobalt DBMs. The materials prepared initially displayed an obvious ability to reversibly sorb a variety of organic components, sometimes with a color change evident. The characterization of these materials proved difficult as only powderlike impure mixtures were isolated, and neither composition nor structure could be determined properly. Substantial progress in this work was achieved after zinc DBM, which forms weaker coordination compounds, was utilized. In many cases, zinc materials were of acceptable quality, with a number of crystalline inclusion products being isolated. This paper reports selected results clearly demonstrating the templating ability of a guest solvent in the formation of certain oligomeric or polymeric host complexes.

elements.content: Preparations. Chemicals. Zinc dibenzoylmethanate (Zn(DBM)2) was prepared as reported elsewhere. The main chemicals and solvents were from Aldrich, with purity of 98% for 4,4‘-dipyridyl (bipy) and 99% or higher for tert- butylbenzene, fluorobenzene, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), tetrahydrofuran (THF), and 2-pentanone. The remaining solvents were of reagent grade quality or higher.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Preparations. Chemicals. Zinc dibenzoylmethanate (Zn(DBM)2) was prepared as reported elsewhere. The main chemicals and solvents were from Aldrich, with purity of 98% for 4,4‘-dipyridyl (bipy) and 99% or higher for tert- butylbenzene, fluorobenzene, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), tetrahydrofuran (THF), and 2-pentanone. The remaining solvents were of reagent grade quality or higher.

elements.content: General Crystallization Procedure. The synthesis of most products was performed in one step. Zn(DBM)2 (256 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in a minimal amount of hot solvent (∼10 mL or more). To this solution was added a hot solution of bipy (86 mg, 0.55 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL of the same solvent. The solution was allowed to cool slowly. Depending on the solvent used, crystalline products formed either instantly or after several hours and, in some cases, after several days. Each crystallization was performed at least twice for consistency. With some solvents, a variable Zn(DBM)2-to-bipy ratio was used.

Crystallizations from tert-Butylbenzene. More than 20 crystallizations were performed from this solvent under various conditions, but satisfactory reproducibility was not achieved. Crystals of two inclusion compounds for single-crystal XRD analysis were found by random selection. For elucidating the composition of the solid phase in this system, a series of six samples was prepared and studied by the powder XRD method. Each sample contained 0.5 mmol (256 mg) of Zn(DBM)2, 70 mmol (9.4 g) of tert-butylbenzene, and a variable amount of bipy:  0.5, 0.75, 1.0, 1.5, 2.5, and 5.0 mmol for samples 1−6, respectively. A drop of pyridine was added to each sample to accelerate ligand exchange. The samples were equilibrated with stirring for 2 days at 50 °C and for the next 2 days at room temperature. It was assumed that the system attained equilibrium as no significant change was detected upon further stirring. The solid phase was separated and studied with powder XRD. By comparing experimental and theoretical powder diffractograms, solid phases from samples 1 and 6 corresponded to pure [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·(tert-butylbenzene) and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·n(bipy)·2n(tert-butylbenzene), respectively (see Supporting Information). Composition of the solid phase from other samples was estimated from intensities of five reference reflections belonging to each of the two phases.

elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ]. Zn(DBM)2 (1.02 g, 2 mmol) and bipy (0.328 g, 2.1 mmol) were dissolved in hot THF (∼20 mL); cooling of the clear solution resulted in needlelike crystals of the inclusion compound with THF. The crystals were separated and desolvated in air for several hours to give 1.1 g (80%) of final product. See Results and Discussion for characterization.

The crystals were separated and desolvated in air for several hours to give 1.1 g (80%) of final product. See Results and Discussion for characterization.

elements.content: Methods. Thermogravimetric Analysis. A 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer (TA Instruments) was utilized. Samples of 10−20 mg were studied in a linear heating mode (5 deg/min) under a nitrogen purge. Crystals of the inclusion compounds were taken from the corresponding mother solutions, crushed, and pressed to dryness between two pieces of blotting paper.

elements.content: Powder XRD Analysis. Phase analyses were performed with a Rigaku Geigerflex diffractometer (Co Kα radiation, λ = 1.7902 Å) in a 5−30° 2θ range, with a 0.02° step scan with 1 s/step. Inclusion compounds with volatile guests were recorded in an atmosphere of the correspondent guest solvent. For theoretical powder diffractograms, the low-temperature single-crystal analysis results (Table ) were used with unit cell dimensions determined at room temperature (Table ).

Single-Crystal XRD Analysis. Single-crystal diffraction experiments were performed with crystals, or chips cut therefrom, taken directly from under their respective mother solutions and cooled immediately to −100 °C. A Siemens SMART CCD X-ray diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å) was used to collect diffraction data. An empirical absorption correction SADABS was applied. The final unit cell parameters were obtained using the entire data sets. The structures were solved by direct methods followed by differential Fourier synthesis, using the SIR92 and SHELXTL 37 packages. The structural refinement was performed on F 2 using all data with positive intensities. Crystal data and experimental details of the low-temperature experiments are listed in Table .

elements.content: The results of guest occupancy refinement are shown in Table . Significant deviations from ideal stoichiometry were observed only for the THF inclusion compound; therefore, for all the remaining structures, total guest occupancy was fixed at ideal values in final cycles of refinement. The largest residual extrema on the final difference map were about zinc atoms or were associated with disordered guest molecules. Specific solution problems encountered in most difficult cases are summarized below.

elements.content: [Zn 2 (bipy)(DBM) 4 ]·(tert-butylbenzene): Residual centers on the electronic density difference map indicated disordering of the host dimer; a satisfactory solution was obtained with the Zn−bipy−Zn fragment disordered over two positions.

elements.content: [Zn 3 (bipy) 2 (DBM) 6 ]·5(DMSO): Testing a preliminary solution of the structure with PLATON indicated missed translation symmetry corresponding to a halved c axis; the smaller unit cell was finally selected. Disordered guest DMSO molecules were treated as rigid molecules, but in some cases, only sulfur atoms with partial occupancy could be resolved.

elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ]n·2n(THF): The presence of translational pseudosymmetry made the application of direct methods difficult. The structure was initially solved in space group P1 and subsequently transformed to P-1 using PLATON. No additional symmetry, which might be suspected from the presence of two chemically equivalent fragments, was found. Minor orientations of disordered guest molecules were represented as isoelectronic cyclopentane molecules.

elements.content: NMR Spectroscopy. 13C Cross-polarization/magic angle spinning (CP/MAS) NMR spectra were obtained at 75.43 MHz at room temperature on a Bruker AMX300 spectrometer equipped with a Doty Scientific 5-mm CP/MAS probe. Samples of compounds with included fluorobenzene were recorded with an excess of guest (a drop was added to the sample in the NMR rotor before capping) to prevent them from desolvation. A standard CP pulse program was used with fixed-amplitude 1H decoupling during signal acquisition. 1H 90° pulse lengths were 2.7−3.05 μs, CP times were 0.7−3 ms, and recycle times were 2−16 s, depending on the sample. Dipolar dephased spectra were obtained by interrupting the 1H decoupling for 40 μs immediately after the CP sequence and before starting the data acquisition. Chemical shifts were measured relative to external solid hexamethylbenzene and then corrected to the TMS scale. Spinning speeds were set in the range 5.7−6.54 kHz to avoid overlap of spinning sidebands with isotropically shifted lines as far as possible.

elements.content: Isolated Materials. Solvent-Free Products. Two solvent-free products were isolated in this work: [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2]. Powder diffractograms of the initial [Zn(DBM)2] (monomeric form of zinc dibenzoylmethanate)36 and the two isolated complexes are shown in Figure . Both complexes were white and stable in air at room temperature. At elevated temperatures (>140 °C), [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] decomposed to [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] (Figure ), while the latter decomposed irreversibly at >245 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Isolated Materials. Solvent-Free Products. Two solvent-free products were isolated in this work: [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2]. Powder diffractograms of the initial [Zn(DBM)2] (monomeric form of zinc dibenzoylmethanate)36 and the two isolated complexes are shown in Figure . Both complexes were white and stable in air at room temperature. At elevated temperatures (>140 °C), [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] decomposed to [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] (Figure ), while the latter decomposed irreversibly at >245 °C.

elements.content: [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] precipitated as a fine-crystalline product from n-heptane, cyclopentane, methylcyclohexane, pinene, 1,2-dichloropropane, hexachloropropene, 2-bromobutane, 1-bromohexane, 1-bromooctane, 2,2-dichloro-1,1,1-trifluoroethane, 1-butanol, 2-butanol, 1-heptanol, pinacolone, methylformate, n-butyl acetate, and nitromethane. The products from all these solvents were identical, displaying very similar powder XRD (Figure b) and TGA (Figure ) patterns. Attempts to obtain the complex as larger crystals failed. Microscope images suggested formation of small needlelike crystals in all cases, with typical dimensions of 4 × 90 μm (see Figure S1 in Supporting Information). The morphology of the crystals suggested the formation of a single phase rather than a mixture. As attested by powder XRD (Figure b), the same phase formed in the course of a TGA experiment and displayed a plateau of thermal stability in the 168−247 °C temperature range (cf. Figure ). From its stoichiometry and by comparison with the structures of some inclusion compounds reported later in this work, it is proposed that the complex forms dinuclear molecules with two zinc centers connected with bridging bipy and two DBMs chelated to each zinc center completing its coordination number to five.

elements.content: The [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] complex was prepared by desolvation of inclusion compounds with THF or 2-pentanone, which are described later in this work. The product was a powder, with a particle size of <2 μm that suggested destruction of the included phase upon removal of the guest THF from the crystalline inclusion compound. The TGA pattern (Figure ) demonstrates the thermal stability of the product up to 142 °C where it shows mass loss of 11.6% in one simple step (11.7% calculated for loss of half of bipy); the result gives evidence that the complex is most probably an individual phase. Taking into account the polymeric structure of the complex in the inclusion compound with THF and the extremely fast desolvation of the inclusion to the solvent-free product, it might be expected that the product could also retain a polymeric structure with endless linear bridging of zinc centers by bipy ligands and two DBMs chelated to each zinc in the equatorial plane.

Inclusions Isolated from tert-Butylbenzene. The system Zn(DBM)2−bipy−tert-butylbenzene was studied in more detail as the formation of two inclusion products complicated the synthesis with unpredictable precipitation of one of the products or their mixtures. In most cases, crystals of both inclusions were of poor quality and coexisted in the same vial. By performing many crystallizations under various conditions, suitable crystals of both inclusions were eventually isolated and studied, thus making it possible to assign the following formulas:  [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·(tert-butylbenzene) and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·n(bipy)·2n(tert-butylbenzene). The former has a dimeric host complex with 1:1 host-to-guest ratio while the latter has a polymeric host included with one bipy and two tert-butylbenzene guests for each zinc DBM unit. Both inclusions in crystalline form were stable in air for several days.

 Inclusions Isolated from tert-Butylbenzene. The system Zn(DBM)2-bipy-tert-butylbenzene was studied in more detail as the formation of two inclusion products complicated the synthesis with unpredictable precipitation of one of the products or their mixtures. In most cases, crystals of both inclusions were of poor quality and coexisted in the same vial. By performing many crystallizations under various conditions, suitable crystals of both inclusions were eventually isolated and studied, thus making it possible to assign the following formulas: [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]⋅(tert-butylbenzene) and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ⋅n(bipy)⋅2n(tert-butylbenzene). The former has a dimeric host complex with 1:1 host-to-guest ratio while the latter has a polymeric host included with one bipy and two tert-butylbenzene guests for each zinc DBM unit. Both inclusions in crystalline form were stable in air for several days.

elements.content: To locate approximate crystallization conditions of the products in the system, a series of mixtures with different zinc DBM-to-bipy ratios was equilibrated as described in the Experimental Section, followed by a powder XRD analysis of the isolated solid-phase precipitates. The solid phase from the sample with 1:1 Zn(DBM)2-to-bipy ratio contained mainly the [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·(tert-butylbenzene) product, while a similar synthesis with a 1:10 ratio resulted in the [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·n(bipy)·2n(tert-butylbenzene) phase (for the comparison of experimental and theoretical powder diffractograms, see the Supporting Information). With 1:1.5, 1:2, 1:3, and 1:5 ratios, mixtures with approximate fractions of 0.5, 0.16, 0.08, and <0.06 of [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·(tert-butylbenzene) phase were obtained, respectively.

With 1:1.5, 1:2, 1:3, and 1:5 ratios, mixtures with approximate fractions of 0.5, 0.16, 0.08, and <0.06 of [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]⋅(tert-butylbenzene) phase were obtained, respectively.

elements.content: From many such observations, we conclude that the formation of one or the other inclusion compound in this system is controlled by both kinetic and thermodynamic factors. The host component has an essentially different molecular structure in the two compounds, dimeric and polymeric, and both dimeric and longer complex species may be available in the crystallization supernatant fluid. Thus, any of the phases may start to crystallize as a result of accidental nucleation, or indeed, both phases may form simultaneously while further conversion between the two phases may be complicated by the necessity of forming or breaking of coordination bonds during the molecular oligomerization/dissociation. Equilibrating the system results in a phase distribution correlating with the zinc DBM-to-bipy ratio in the initial mixture. As one of the compounds has this ratio at 1:1/2 and the other at 1:2, an excess of bipy shifts the overall equilibrium toward the preferred formation of the latter phase.

elements.content: Inclusions Isolated from Fluorobenzene. The system Zn(DBM)2−bipy−fluorobenzene is complicated in a similar way, producing two inclusion compounds, [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·2/3(fluorobenzene) and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·2n(fluorobenzene). Both inclusions were characterized with single-crystal XRD and solid-state 13C NMR methods, as described later in the work. The former has dimeric host complexes with 1:2/3 host per guest ratio while the latter has polymeric host included with two guest molecules per each zinc DBM unit. Both inclusions lost guest in air.

elements.content: As a rule, crystallizations led to a single inclusion phase at first, but subsequent regrowing into another phase was observed in some cases. The formation of a desired inclusion phase might be controlled to some degree by varying the initial zinc DBM-to-bipy ratio, as the two phases have the 1:1/2 and 1:1 ratios of these components, but random factors still played a significant role in the crystallization process. Therefore, preparation of monophase bulk products was attainable through multiple attempts at crystallization. The isolated bulk products exhibited powder diffractograms in very good accordance with theoretical diffractograms calculated for pure compounds from the single-crystal XRD experiments (see Supporting Information). [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·2/3(fluorobenzene) crystallized in the form of isometric crystals (“blocks”) unstable in air; the product showed 5.8% mass loss in TGA analysis (T o = 118 °C); 5.1% was expected for the loss of the fluorobenzene guest. [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·2n(fluorobenzene) crystallized in the form of prisms or needles also unstable in air; the product showed 22.4% mass loss in TGA analysis (T o = 59 °C); 22.3% was expected for the loss of the fluorobenzene guest.

elements.content: Inclusions Isolated from DMSO. From DMSO, two inclusion compounds were isolated as bulk crystalline (prisms) products, [Zn3(bipy)2(DBM)6]·5(DMSO) and [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·1/2 n(bipy)·1/2 n(DMSO). The former compound reproducibly formed over a wide range of crystallization conditions, with zinc DBM per bipy ratios of 1:1, 1:1.5, and 1:2. The latter formed at a zinc DBM per bipy ratio of 1:3 and with greater bipy excess. The former decomposed in air (to solvent-free host) in several days, and the latter revealed higher stability. Both inclusions were characterized with single-crystal XRD and solid-state 13C NMR methods, as described later in the work. Powder diffractograms of the bulk products corresponded very well to theoretical diffractograms for pure compounds (see Supporting Information). [Zn3(bipy)2(DBM)6]·5(DMSO) has a trimeric host complex with three zinc centers bridged with two bipy ligands in a linear fashion; each zinc is chelated additionally with two DBM anions. The central zinc has octahedral coordination with two DBMs in the equatorial plane and the bipy's nitrogens coordinated axially while the terminal zincs are five-coordinated. The host-to-guest ratio is 1:5. [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·1/2 n(bipy)·1/2 n(DMSO) has a polymeric host with included bipy and DMSO guests half of each for one zinc DBM unit.

elements.content: Inclusions Isolated from THF and 2-Pentanone. From these two solvents, isostructural inclusion compounds formed. The inclusion compound with THF was studied by single-crystal XRD analysis revealing its formula to be [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·2n(THF). The ideal (structural) host per guest stoichiometry is 1:9/4, but the observed guest occupancy was lower to give a 1:1.97(1) ratio. The inclusion with 2-pentanone has unit cell dimensions that are similar to the THF inclusion, suggesting a similar structure. Both inclusions crystallized in the form of long needles that were extremely unstable in air. Rapid desolvation was observed unless the whole crystal was covered with mother liquor. Because of the instability of these inclusions, no further studies were performed.

elements.content: Structural Studies of Isolated Inclusion Compounds. General Comments. All structures studied are governed by van der Waals forces, with seven distinct structures determined in this study. Each has low symmetry and shows increased complexity. The Zn(DBM)2 unit complemented with pyridyl moieties is a rather simple fragment that might well possess relatively high-symmetry mmm or 222; however, the maximum symmetry observed in the structures were 2 or −1. Most structures were triclinic. In most cases the guest molecules were disordered, and in many cases disorder of the host fragments was also found. All these observations indicate increased packing problems presumably arising from a restriction of Zn(DBM)2 units into covalently bonded oligo- or polymeric structure of the host subsystem.
elements.clean_text: Structural Studies of Isolated Inclusion Compounds.  General Comments. All structures studied are governed by van der Waals forces, with seven distinct structures determined in this study. Each has low symmetry and shows increased complexity. The Zn(DBM)2 unit complemented with pyridyl moieties is a rather simple fragment that might well possess relatively high-symmetry mmm or 222; however, the maximum symmetry observed in the structures were 2 or -1. Most structures were triclinic. In most cases the guest molecules were disordered, and in many cases disorder of the host fragments was also found. All these observations indicate increased packing problems presumably arising from a restriction of Zn(DBM)2 units into covalently bonded oligo- or polymeric structure of the host subsystem.

elements.content: Molecular Structure of the Host Species. The three types of host species observed in the present study are shown in Figure . Dimeric [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] host species were found in two structures, trimeric [Zn3(bipy)2(DBM)6] in one structure and polymeric [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n host chains in the remaining four structures. As shown in Figure f, the three types form in the same way but have a different number (k) of intermediate units with six-coordinated zinc. Terminal units have five-coordinated zinc.

As shown in Figure f, the three types form in the same way but have a different number (k) of intermediate units with six-coordinated zinc. Terminal units have five-coordinated zinc.

elements.content: For five-coordinated zinc, the length of the coordination bond varies within 1.97−2.10 Å (statistics for 25 independent bonds) with no notable differences between Zn−O and Zn−N distances. In three cases, the coordination polyhedron for zinc is well described as a trigonal bipyramid, with most coordination angles not deviating by more than 5° from ideal. For example, the dimeric molecule shown in Figure a has atom ZnB surrounded with apical O1B and O4B and equatorial O3B, O6B, and N8B atoms. The other end of the molecule is the only case that has a zinc atom, ZnA, in a coordination environment intermediate between a trigonal bipyramid (with apical O3A and O6A) and a square pyramid (with apical N7A), with average angular deviations from the ideal polyhedra of 9.9° and 10.2°, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal packing in the [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·(tert-butylbenzene) inclusion compound:  (a) interdigitation of two host dimeric molecules that result in mutual partial filling of their pockets; (b) host content of the unit cell and location of guest molecules in residual halves of the host pockets. Here and in subsequent figures host molecules are displayed in wire-frame style and guest molecules as ball and stick; H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: For six-coordinated zinc, a distorted octahedral environment was observed with a distinct differentiation between equatorial and axial bonds. The length of the equatorial Zn−O bond varies within 2.05−2.09 Å (24 bonds), while the axial Zn−N bond varies within 2.14−2.26 Å (12 bonds). The shortening of equatorial bonds may result from some conjugation between two parts of the bis-chelate fragment, which is possible when the fragments are nearly coplanar; this point was discussed in our earlier papers. Angular deviations from the ideal octahedron do not usually exceed 3° except for [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n · 1/2 n(bipy)· 1/2 n(DMSO), where deviations of up to 5° were observed. It should be noted that in all cases six-coordinated zinc was found in the trans isomeric configuration.
elements.clean_text: For six-coordinated zinc, a distorted octahedral environment was observed with a distinct differentiation between equatorial and axial bonds. The length of the equatorial Zn-O bond varies within 2.05-2.09 Å (24 bonds), while the axial Zn-N bond varies within 2.14-2.26 Å (12 bonds). The shortening of equatorial bonds may result from some conjugation between two parts of the bis-chelate fragment, which is possible when the fragments are nearly coplanar; this point was discussed in our earlier papers. Angular deviations from the ideal octahedron do not usually exceed 3° except for [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n  ⋅ 1/2 n(bipy)⋅ 1/2 n(DMSO), where deviations of up to 5° were observed. It should be noted that in all cases six-coordinated zinc was found in the trans isomeric configuration.

elements.content: The DBM ligands chelate to zinc atoms forming pseudoaromatic rings, with the zinc atoms deviating not more than by 0.1−0.15 Å from the planes of the rings. Again, the maximum deviations of up to 0.2 Å were found in [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n · 1/2 n(bipy)· 1/2 n(DMSO). In this inclusion, the greatest deviations from planarity of the bis-chelate fragments were observed, with dihedral angles between adjacent O−C−CH−C−O semirings of 133.8° (unit A) and 123.5° (unit B) (Figure c). Planes of phenyl rings of DBM ligands are twisted from planes of chelating rings by 3°−56° with an average dihedral angle of 29(2)° without systematic difference for DBMs of five- and six-coordinated zinc. Some preference of the phenyl rings for coplanarity with the chelating rings seems evident as 82% the dihedral angles do not exceed 45° (statistics for 44 phenyls). The preference may suggest a tendency for conjugation over the whole DBM fragment. Similar observations were reported for simpler metal DBM hosts.

elements.content: The bipy bridging ligands coordinate and serve as spacers between adjacent Zn(DBM)2 units. In many cases the adjacent pyridyl moieties are coplanar for symmetry reasons; in other cases they are twisted by up to 38°. Bidentate coordination to two zinc atoms restricts the distance between the zinc atoms that varies within 11.3−11.6 Å. This distance dictates the size of spaces between Zn(DBM)2 units, this space plays a crucial role in determining the inclusion ability of the complexes.

elements.content: The inclusion ability of simpler metal DBM complexes (Figure e) was understood in terms of the presence of shallow pockets located between pyridyl and DBM fragments. 1-5 In the crystal structures, some of these pockets were filled with fragments from neighboring host molecules, but many could not be filled in this way due to spatial restrictions and thus were available for accommodation of guest species. Host species prepared in the present study have dramatically longer and deeper pockets as formed by DBM units fixed at a distance of more than 1 nm defined by the bipy ligand. Two pockets for each bipy may be distinguished on each side of the bipy spacer. Taking into account van der Waals contours of the atoms, the pocket is 6 Å deep and 8 Å in length in the vicinity of a bipy ligand and up to 12.5 Å in length at outer edges of the molecule.

elements.content: It should be noted that the host complex molecules reported in this study bear certain resemblance to the so-called “wheel-and-axle” and “dumbbell-shape” designed organic hosts. As demonstrated in the present study, these types of host entities are easier achievable using metal DBMs and several different host molecules may be created from the same set of metal center and ligands.

elements.content: [Zn 2 (bipy)(DBM) 4 ]·(tert-butylbenzene). Centrosymmetric host dimers are aligned in the (ac) plane. Half of the host pocket is filled with phenyl fragments of the adjacent host molecules due to partial interdigitation of the host dimers aligned in chains (Figure a). The other half of the pocket is available for guest inclusion. The guest molecule is ∼9.1 Å long and does not fit into the shallow pocket; two host dimers, related by translation along b axis, combine their pockets to make a cavity large enough for the guest (Figure b). As one host dimer accommodates “two halves” of guest molecules, the resulting host per guest ratio is 1:1, thus explaining the total stoichiometry.

elements.content: [Zn 2 (bipy)(DBM) 4 ]· 2 / 3 (fluorobenzene). The structure (Figure ) shows some features similar to those in inclusion with tert-butylbenzene described above. All of the host dimers are aligned in parallel. The chains of interdigitating host molecules run along the c axis in the order (AB)(C)(BA)(AB)(C)(BA). Dimer C interdigitating with two AB dimers has two guest molecules in the remaining parts of its pockets. The smaller size of the guest allows better insertion into the pocket, and neighboring chains are packed closer. This closer packing makes it possible to fill the residual pocket space of the host dimers with phenyl fragments from host units of neighboring chains, and the AB dimers do not have guest in their pockets. Therefore, only one of the three host dimers in the unit cell accommodates two guest molecules that results in the 1:2/3 total stoichiometry.

elements.content: [Zn 3 (bipy) 2 (DBM) 6 ]·5(DMSO). The structure consists of the host trimeric molecules and the guest species accommodated inside nanosized channel cavities. The host trimers are aligned in parallel (Figure a). Each trimer has four large pockets located away from either side of the two bipy ligands. Two pockets are effectively filled with fragments from the terminal zinc DBMs of four adjacent molecules. The other two pockets are partially filled with phenyls from central zinc DBM units of adjacent molecules; the units are almost planar and leave the major parts of the pockets available for guest inclusion. The location of guest molecules around the host trimer is shown in Figure b. Surprisingly, the guest sites occur in groups rather than being distributed throughout the structure. The portions of the pockets available for guest inclusion combine to form a channel stretching through the center of the unit cell along the b direction. The channel is wide at y = 0 and has constrictions at y = 1/2. The wide part is about 10 × 15 Å and 10 Å long, and accommodates four guest molecules. The constriction is about 5 × 6 Å wide and contains only one guest molecule (C). The stoichiometry of the compound of 1:5 is understandable as the channel may be considered as a sequence of cavities containing five guest molecules each, and the two pockets of the host trimer form two halves of the cavities.

elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ] n ·2n(fluorobenzene). Each of two halves (A and B) of the host monomer contains a zinc atom on a special position, one complete DBM group and half of a bridging bipy ligand (consisting of two half-pyridyl rings). Each A and B generates a polymeric chain through the c glide. There are therefore two crystallographically distinct chains in the structure propagating in the c direction, A and B. They van der Waals pack in two other directions. Four chains run through the unit cell (Figure a) mutually filling each of the other pockets with phenyl fragments (Figure b). The distance between the adjacent chains is 9.7 and 9.9 Å along a and b axes, respectively. Guest molecules partially occupy the residual space of the pockets and reside between the chains. Each guest is located in a cavity bounded by two adjacent chains. The 1:2 stoichiometry arises as each section of the host chain provides half-accommodation for four guest molecules. There are no channels evident in the structure. Instability of the compound due to guest loss is explainable, as diffusion of guest species seems possible in all three dimensions taking into account rotational flexibility of the phenyl rings (see NMR studies).

elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ] n ·2n(THF). The asymmetric unit of this structure is the largest in the series; it comprises two adjacent host units (A and B) and four and a half guest molecules. The host chain is completed by a translation parallel to the (bc) plane (Figure ). The zinc DBM bis-chelate fragments of A and B units are bent in the opposite direction so that, along the length of the chain, there is an alternation of longer and shorter void spaces around the chain core (Figure b). The host chains distinctly group in pairs around an inversion center (Figure a). The two chains in the pair interdigitate strongly, the distance between the chains being only 5.7 Å, while the closest chain from another pair is at distance of more than 10.5 Å. The guest molecule, M, is located within the longer void spaces between the interdigitated pair. The guest molecule, E, is located within the short void space between adjacent pairs, while G, I, and L are located within the long void spaces between adjacent pairs. This long space combines with that from another chain pair to form a 13 × 13 Å channel that runs in the a direction through the origin. The movement of the guest molecule inside and along the channel should be very easy, and that explains extreme instability of the inclusion compound when it is out of its mother liquor. It is also interesting that in this structure most guest molecules (E, G, I, M) “belong” to one host chain and only one molecule (L) resides in a cavity space formed by the cooperation of two different chains. This feature defines the ideal host per guest ratio for the compound of 1:9/4 (four and a half guests per two host units).

elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ] n · 1 / 2 n(bipy)· 1 / 2 n(DMSO). The structure is a 1D coordination polymer with the polymeric chains running along the c direction. The guest species are located in the residual channel space. The chains interdigitate along the b direction (Figure a) and there are pairs with a 5.9-Å separation, similar to those in the inclusion compound with THF. These pairs however are packed in a different way, interdigitating with a 7.2-Å separation between chains from adjacent pairs to form a host layer parallel to the (bc) plane. The guest species are located between these layers inside channels running along the b axis (Figure b). The channels are isolated; the channel axis is centered about the origin and the cross section of the channel is an ellipsoid with approximate dimensions of 7 × 13 Å. The guest molecules stretch in two parallel rows in the channel, with bipy and DMSO molecules alternating along each of the rows (Figure c). A segment of the channel accommodating two bipy and two DMSO guest molecules is formed by four pockets associated with the longer void spaces of the host polymeric chains, and there are two such pockets per two zinc DBM units; the resulting host/bipy/DMSO molar ratio is 1:1/2:1/2.

elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ] n ·n(bipy)·2n(tert-butylbenzene). The zinc atom of the host complex is located on an inversion center, and the bipy ligand is located on a 2-fold axis running through the median of C−C bond connecting two pyridyl rings. These two symmetry elements generate host polymeric chain stretching parallel to the (ac) plane. A second chain passing through the unit cell is generated by a second 2-fold axis. The consecutive zinc DBM units along the chain are twisted (Figure a) in way similar to that in the polymeric structure with fluorobenzene (cf. Figure a). However, the packing of the chains is different. The distance between the adjacent chains is 9.8 and 13.6 Å perpendicular and along b axis, respectively. Most of the pocket space between zinc DBM units is available for guest inclusion. This void space combines in a 2D system of intersecting channels running in layers parallel to the (bc) plane. The widest channel with an approximate rectangular cross section of 5 × 9 Å runs along the c direction and accommodates disordered guest (tert-butylbenzene) molecules (Figure b). Each void space between consecutive zinc DBM units in the chain is filled with one bipy and two tert-butylbenzene guest molecules, which results in host/bipy/tert-butylbenzene molar ratio of 1:1:2.

elements.content: NMR Studies. The purpose of the NMR studies was to provide an analytical tool for the bulk materials to confirm the structural results obtained from single crystals and to obtain information about the solvent-free dimer [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] and polymer [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n whose structures were not determined. Figure compares solid-state 13C NMR spectra of Zn(DBM)2, reported previously, and the two isolated complexes. Spectra of the inclusion compounds studied are shown in Figure . What is clear from the outset is that the spectrum for each compound is quite distinct, in keeping with each having its own crystal structure. Previous work on the 13C CP/MAS NMR of Zn(DBM)2 and Zn2(DBM)4 gives the general range of shifts and assignments for DBM complexed to Zn. With this and the available information on 4,4‘-dipyridyl, assignments can then be made for bipy in the new complexes. Dipolar dephased spectra aid in the assignments by indicating the quaternary carbons. There are overlaps in the aromatic carbon region, but the bipy carbons attached to N are distinct (147−154 ppm range) and the bipy carbons adjacent to the ring-linking quaternary carbon appear to be on the low side of the aromatic range (121−124 ppm). The bipy quaternary carbons, which link the two rings, are to the high end of the range for the quaternary phenyl carbons of DBM (137−147 ppm). Assignments of the 13C NMR shifts for all the complexes studied (with the exception of very unstable THF and 2-pentanone inclusions) are given in Table . The spectra are further complicated by those guest molecules that have aromatic carbons, and definite assignments of their resonances could only be made in a few instances.

Intensities. Quantitation from the intensities of lines in a CP/MAS spectrum is complicated by a number of factors (for instance, in some cases the intensity gives an underestimate of the CO carbons), so the derived numbers from our spectra should be treated as semiquantitative. Table compares expected and observed intensities for different regions of the spectra showing a reasonable agreement for the majority of cases.

Multiplicities. NMR can serve as a check on the structural analysis. Chemically equivalent carbons can be crystallographically, and therefore potentially magnetically, distinct. This gives rise to a multiplicity of resonances for a particular type of carbon that cannot be greater than the number of crystallographically distinct atoms in the asymmetric unit. It is possible to say from the multiplicities of the DBM CO and CH resonances for the empty dimer and polymer that these must have at least two and four DBM ligands in their asymmetric units, respectively. For the inclusion compounds, those multiplicities that could be distinguished (without complications due to overlap with other lines) were all consistent with the crystal structures determined. Examples are given in the details below.

Examples are given in the details below.

elements.content: The trimeric structure with DMSO guest has a very rich spectrum due to the large number of atoms in the asymmetric unit, which includes 3 DBM, 1 bipy, and 2.5 DMSO. Though there are five crystallographically distinct DMSO methyl groups, they are not distinguished in the single line at 40.6 ppm. The DBM methanate C−H carbons show as a 1:2 doublet and the CO carbons as a 1:2:2:1 quartet (with one of the doublets showing a very slight splitting). These results are quite consistent with there being three DBMs in the asymmetric unit. The observed intensity ratio of DMSO carbons to the total host carbons is 1:11.1 (cf. expected 1:11).

elements.content: In the polymeric structure with fluorobenzene, the C−F carbon resonance is a doublet (164.9, 161.5 ppm), which might have been taken as distinguishing the two distinct guest molecules; however, the splitting (∼256 Hz) is of the same order as the reported J(13C−19F) coupling (245.3 Hz) for the liquid, which should still be present in the solid. The DBM methanate C−H shows as a doublet, consistent with the two separate polymer chains A and B in the structure. The spectrum of the less stable dimer with fluorobenzene is markedly different and less well resolved, which may reflect some inhomogeneity arising from partial desolvation. Nevertheless the methanate C−H shows as a quartet of lines, consistent with the structural data.

elements.content: Dynamics. Residual intensity for proton-bearing carbons in the dipolar dephased spectra indicates the presence of dynamics. Methyl reorientation is quite common, and thus the methyl carbons of DMSO and tert-butylbenzene are readily seen. The fluorobenzene molecule also shows dynamics in both of the complexes studied. There are also indications of bipy reorientation in the polymer with fluorobenzene and the polymer with tert-butylbenzene/bipy. As was found previously for the Zn/DBM complexes, there is evidence of reorientation of the DBM phenyl rings about their 2-fold axes in that the ortho and meta resonances show residual intensity but the para resonance does not.

elements.content: General Discussion. As the most important result, this work demonstrates that new metal DBM host complexes may be generated not only by exchanging metal and ligands in the basic unit but also by connecting these units together. The resulting oligo- and polymeric host receptors show enhanced inclusion ability and enlarged size of the cavity space, as compared with the mononuclear metal DBM complexes reported previously.
elements.clean_text: General Discussion. As the most important result, this work demonstrates that new metal DBM host complexes may be generated not only by exchanging metal and ligands in the basic unit but also by connecting these units together. The resulting oligo- and polymeric host receptors show enhanced inclusion ability and enlarged size of the cavity space, as compared with the mononuclear metal DBM complexes reported previously.

elements.content: The ability of modified metal DBM complexes to entrap solvent molecules is the result of the poor ability of these complexes to pack efficiently in three dimensions. The entrapped molecules improve the packing efficiency. Extension of the complexes to multinuclear species appears to be a new way to reduce their ability to pack efficiently. This strategy appears to be more effective than increasing size of the neutral ligand used, as it decreases the translational and rotational freedom of the species. Consequently, the nuclearity of the host complex may be expected to correlate with its inclusion ability. Results of the present work are in good accordance with this expectation. The dimeric complex produced inclusion compounds with tert-butylbenzene and fluorobenzene but precipitated as a solvent-free form from 17 other solvents tested. In contrast, the polymeric complex produced inclusion compounds with a wide range of solvents but never crystallized in a solvent-free form.

elements.content: The size of the host complexes increases dramatically upon oligomerization. The maximum van der Waals dimension of the dimeric [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] complex exceeds 27 Å and that of the trimeric [Zn3(bipy)2(DBM)6] complex exceeds 38 Å. The void space between adjacent zinc DBM units is significantly greater than the shallow pockets found in mononuclear metal DBMs. Interdigitation of the host oligomeric molecules or host polymeric chains does not result in close packing, and the residual cavity space is large enough to accommodate up to three average-sized guest molecules for each zinc DBM unit. When the space between adjacent zinc DBM units is fully available for inclusion, up to five guest molecules may be accommodated in one cavity, or two rows of guest molecules may fit into one channel. The dimension of the cavity space can vary up to 1−2 nm in many cases. It is clear therefore that the polynuclear metal DBMs have the potential for generating supramolecular materials with nanosized pore space.

elements.content: An interesting observation of this work is that guest molecules can be associated with characteristic pocket space already available on a host molecule. Also, in many cases, the guest species are concentrated in groups inside large cavities rather than evenly distributed within the structure. There are two types of host molecules: Molecules of the first type do not possess cavity space themselves but create it upon assembling in solid state; gossypol, urea, Werner complexes, and water are a few examples of this type. Molecules of the second type already possess cavity space and often are referred to as “receptors”; calixarenes, carcerands, and cyclodextrins are among the most common representatives. The host molecules examined in this study are intermediate between these two types, but their resemblance to the second type is greater than for other metal complexes, including mononuclear metal DBM hosts. This observation allows us to use term “receptor” even though no data on inclusion in single host molecule are available.

elements.content: Despite the structural variety of compounds reported in this work, common features in the host molecular structure and crystal packing may be readily recognized. The growth of the host units occurs due to insertion of host monomeric units with six-coordinated zinc between terminal host units with five-coordinated zinc. The former unit is always trans-configured, which necessarily produces a linear arrangement of the host molecules. In the crystal structure, the host molecules are always aligned in parallel, as has been previously noted for other elongated and polymeric35,60-62 complexes. The needle- or prismlike habit of most of the isolated crystals, which seems to reflect this form of crystal packing, is most noticeable upon fast growth of the crystals. A parallel alignment of the host species is understandable, as it allows interdigitation. Still, the host species are not able to pack efficiently despite the intrinsic high flexibility of that metal coordination environment that can be dramatically distorted in some cases. The observed loose packing leads to residual cavity spaces that often combine in one or both other directions of the crystal structure.

elements.content: Another important result of this work is that the formation of the host species of specific nuclearity is determined by the guest template. tert-Butylbenzene, DMSO, and THF exemplify specific templates inducing formation of dimeric, trimeric, and polymeric host species, respectively. Guest-induced change of the molecular structure of host complexes is an attractive but still not well explored way to switch bulk properties of supramolecular materials. 17 Guest-supported stabilization in supramolecular solids of molecular conformations, spatial isomers, and the molecules themselves was traced in the literature, but there seemed to be very few examples of guest-supported stabilization of an oligomeric host complex.

elements.content: tert-Butylbenzene acts as a specific template for the dimeric [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4] (Zn:bipy = 1:1/2) host complex. An excess of bipy was applied in an attempt to shift the equilibrium into formation of the polymeric [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n (Zn:bipy = 1:1) complex with included tert-butylbenzene. However, tert-butylbenzene alone is not able to support the formation of the polymer, and instead, the compound [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n · n(bipy)·2n(tert-butylbenzene) (Zn:bipy = 1:2) forms. This compound contains bipy included as guest, thus playing the role of a polymer template, together with tert-butylbenzene.

This compound contains bipy included as guest, thus playing the role of a polymer template, together with tert-butylbenzene.

elements.content: Inclusion of the same molecule both as a part of the host complex and as a guest in the same compound has been observed and discussed before, and the inclusion of bipy in such instance was recently demonstrated. It is quite surprising though that inclusion of bipy occurs even upon application of 2 orders molar concentration excess of tert-butylbenzene. Both guest bipy and tert-butylbenzene interact with the host lattice by van Waals forces only, and the resulting structure must reflect the spatial complementarity.

elements.content:
These studies have shown that fluorobenzene directs oligomerization of zinc DBM units into either dimers or polymers but never induces the formation of trimers.

DMSO is the only template that we have found for the trimeric host species, and it is very specific. The inclusion compound [Zn3(bipy)2(DBM)6]·5(DMSO) (Zn:bipy = 1:2/3) forms as the only product in a range of concentrations of up to 3-fold excess of bipy over zinc DBM. Increased excess bipy again leads to inclusion of the ligand as guest molecule to produce the solvated host polymer, [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n · 1/2 n(bipy)· 1/2 n(DMSO). The polymeric host thus forms in DMSO only upon templating with these two molecules, bipy and DMSO, together.

Increased excess bipy again leads to inclusion of the ligand as guest molecule to produce the solvated host polymer, [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n  ⋅ 1/2 n(bipy)⋅ 1/2 n(DMSO). The polymeric host thus forms in DMSO only upon templating with these two molecules, bipy and DMSO, together.

elements.content:
THF and 2-pentanone are examples of guest types that induce formation of a solvated polymeric host, and the polymeric structure of the host complex seems to remain upon desolvation.

Two solvent-free and eight inclusion compounds reported in this work elucidate a rich supramolecular chemistry in the metal DBM−bipy−guest systems. These compounds exhibit significant chemical, stoichiometric, and structural diversity. The zinc DBM-to-bipy ratio takes five different values ranging from 1:1/2 to 1:2; the host-to-guest ratio takes six different values ranging from 1:1 to 1:5. Dimeric, trimeric, or polymeric host complexes form in the system depending on the initial concentrations and specific geometry of the guest template. The crystal structures reveal complexity and dramatic differences in topology. At the same time, along with their complexity and diversity, the systems demonstrate the remarkably high inclusion potential of oligomeric and polymeric metal DBMs. The complexes may serve as building elements for coordination oligo- and polymeric materials possessing interesting properties and important functions as those reported in the very recent literature.

cln_elements.content: [Zn(bipy)(DBM) 2 ]. Zn(DBM)2 (1.02 g, 2 mmol) and bipy (0.328 g, 2.1 mmol) were dissolved in hot THF (∼20 mL); cooling of the clear solution resulted in needlelike crystals of the inclusion compound with THF. The crystals were separated and desolvated in air for several hours to give 1.1 g (80%) of final product. See Results and Discussion for characterization.

cln_elements.content:
The [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] complex was prepared by desolvation of inclusion compounds with THF or 2-pentanone, which are described later in this work. The product was a powder, with a particle size of <2 μm that suggested destruction of the included phase upon removal of the guest THF from the crystalline inclusion compound. The TGA pattern (Figure ) demonstrates the thermal stability of the product up to 142 °C where it shows mass loss of 11.6% in one simple step (11.7% calculated for loss of half of bipy); the result gives evidence that the complex is most probably an individual phase. Taking into account the polymeric structure of the complex in the inclusion compound with THF and the extremely fast desolvation of the inclusion to the solvent-free product, it might be expected that the product could also retain a polymeric structure with endless linear bridging of zinc centers by bipy ligands and two DBMs chelated to each zinc in the equatorial plane.

As a rule, crystallizations led to a single inclusion phase at first, but subsequent regrowing into another phase was observed in some cases. The formation of a desired inclusion phase might be controlled to some degree by varying the initial zinc DBM-to-bipy ratio, as the two phases have the 1:1/2 and 1:1 ratios of these components, but random factors still played a significant role in the crystallization process. Therefore, preparation of monophase bulk products was attainable through multiple attempts at crystallization. The isolated bulk products exhibited powder diffractograms in very good accordance with theoretical diffractograms calculated for pure compounds from the single-crystal XRD experiments (see Supporting Information). [Zn2(bipy)(DBM)4]·2/3(fluorobenzene) crystallized in the form of isometric crystals (“blocks”) unstable in air; the product showed 5.8% mass loss in TGA analysis (T o = 118 °C); 5.1% was expected for the loss of the fluorobenzene guest. [Zn(bipy)(DBM)2] n ·2n(fluorobenzene) crystallized in the form of prisms or needles also unstable in air; the product showed 22.4% mass loss in TGA analysis (T o = 59 °C); 22.3% was expected for the loss of the fluorobenzene guest.
